title: Lavender Tallow Balm: What Actually Happened to My Skin This Winter
body:
Okay so I was using this CeraVe cream. The big tub. You know the one. Everyone says it’s the best. My skin was still so dry it felt like paper. Like, tight paper. In the middle of winter. I’d put it on and an hour later my cheeks were flaking again. It was so frustrating. I was spending money on this stuff that was supposed to be a miracle and my face just felt… worse? I don’t know. I was annoyed. Anyway, that’s when I started looking at other stuff and kept seeing people talk about beef tallow balm. For your face. Which sounded completely insane to me. Like, cooking fat? On my skin? But I was desperate. So I ordered this whipped tallow balm with lavender from some small shop on Etsy. Figured I’d try it. Worst case, I’m out thirty bucks and I have a weird story.

Here’s what happened.

## How I Ended Up Putting Beef Fat on My Face

Look, I need to back up. My skin gets so bad in winter. It’s not just dry. It’s angry. Red patches. Itchy. The skin on my knuckles would crack. It was gross. I tried everything. That CeraVe stuff. Then some La Roche-Posay thing my friend swore by. That was like forty dollars for a tiny tube. Felt nice going on but did nothing. Absolutely nothing. My sink was full of half-used bottles. It was a graveyard of things that didn’t work.

So I’m scrolling online one night, it was probably 11 PM, and I see this post about tallow skincare. Natural vs commercial skincare, all that. People were saying it mimics your skin’s own oils so it actually gets absorbed. Doesn’t just sit on top. I was skeptical. Very skeptical. But the logic kind of made sense? Our skin likes oil. Beef fat is… oil. From an animal. We’re animals. I don’t know. It was late. I was tired of my face hurting. I clicked buy on this lavender tallow balm. The listing said it was whipped tallow from grass-fed cows. Made in France. Sounded fancy for being basically rendered fat.

It arrived in a little jar. Smelled like lavender. Not a fake candle smell. More like… actual dried lavender. Maybe a little earthy. I opened it and poked it. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. Kind of dense but soft. Like cold butter that’s been whipped. I was sitting at my kitchen table, the overhead light was too bright, and I’m thinking “I am about to smear cow fat on my face.” What a time to be alive.

## What This Lavender Tallow Balm Actually Does

So the first time I used it, I braced for grease. That’s what I expected. A greasy film that would get on my pillow.

But get this—it wasn’t like that at all.

I took a little scoop. It felt cool. I rubbed it between my fingers to warm it up. Then I just put it on my face. On the dry patches. On my cheeks and forehead. It went on kind of waxy? But then it just… sank in. I kept waiting for the shiny film. It never came. My skin just felt calm. Not oily. Not greasy. Just… normal. Hydrated. The tight, papery feeling was gone. Actually gone. I remember looking in the mirror like an hour later and poking my cheek. It was soft. Not “product” soft. Just skin soft.

I started using it every night. The lavender smell is strong but in a good way. It’s not perfume. It’s herbal. It smells like the plant. It made the whole routine feel kind of… intentional? Like a little ritual before bed. I’d put it on, the smell would fill the room, and I’d just knock out. It’s definitely relaxing. More than any “sleep-promoting” spray I’ve bought.

The big test was my hands. My knuckles were a disaster. Red, cracked, they’d sometimes bleed if I made a fist. I started slathering this tallow balm on them before bed and wearing cotton gloves. Sounds extra, I know. But after three nights, the cracks started closing up. After a week, they were just… normal hands. Not baby soft. Just not painful. That was the real moment for me. When a thirty-dollar jar of beef fat fixed what decades of commercial lotions couldn’t.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

I’ve been using it for like, two months now. Maybe three. I lost track.

The difference isn’t dramatic in a “wow you look 20 years younger” way. It’s subtle. My skin just… doesn’t freak out anymore. No more random dry patches. No more flakiness around my nose. When I wake up, my face doesn’t feel tight. It just feels like my face. I used to have this little patch of eczema on my elbow since I was a kid. It’s pretty much gone now. I just put the tallow on it because why not. And it just faded away.

I think that’s the thing with this best natural moisturizer stuff. It doesn’t perform a miracle. It just gives your skin what it actually needs. The tallow is so similar to our own sebum that my skin just accepts it. It’s not fighting a layer of silicone or mineral oil. It’s just getting moisture that it recognizes. That’s the whole natural vs commercial skincare thing, I guess. One is trying to trick your skin. The other is just… feeding it.

I told my mom about it. She thought I was nuts. Then her hands got bad from all the winter gardening and she tried some of mine. Now she wants her own jar. I’m on my second one now. I got it from the same Etsy shop. The seller is just some person making it in small batches. I like that. Feels less weird than giving my money to a giant corporation for a cream that didn’t work.

## Would I Buy This Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did.

It’s become my go-to for everything. Dry knees? Tallow. Rough feet? Tallow. My face at night? Lavender tallow balm. It’s the only product on my nightstand now. I got rid of the CeraVe tub. It’s sitting under my sink for… I don’t know. Elbow grease? Not skin grease.

It’s not magic. If you have serious skin issues, see a doctor. But for regular winter dryness, for skin that just feels angry and neglected, this stuff works. It genuinely works. I didn’t expect it to. I thought it was a crunchy gimmick. But my skin is happier. I’m happier not spending a fortune. That’s the tallow balm review, I guess.

It’s simple. It’s kind of weird when you explain it. But it just… does the job.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yes. From what I read, the fat molecules are really close to what our skin makes naturally. So it absorbs deep instead of sitting on top. My face seems to think it’s good, anyway. It stopped being so dry.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
I was worried about that. But no, not for me. It sinks right in. My skin isn’t oily, it’s just hydrated. I think because it’s so similar to our own oils, our skin knows what to do with it. No breakouts.

**What does lavender tallow balm smell like?**
Like real lavender. Not a fake air freshener. It’s earthy and herbal. Strong when you open the jar, but it fades pretty fast after you put it on. It’s calming. Makes the whole thing feel like a bedtime ritual.

Anyway. If your skin’s being difficult and the usual stuff isn’t cutting it, this might be worth a shot. It was for me. My elbows haven’t been this normal since I was a kid. So yeah. It just works.
